AttributeValuesData.AttributeValue: a medium- to large-sized vase-like tree that grows in most any environment
2-4” long, alternate, fine-toothed and oval; medium green color
gray-brown with distinctive rough, corky or warty ridges
small ¼” berry-like fruit; turns from orange-red to purple when ripe

The Hackberry is a long-lived, rapid growing, native tree that can be found throughout much of the upper Midwest. The Hackberry resembles the American elm in several ways. Both are vase-shaped with arching branches when mature; both have a finely-sawed alternate leaf; and both have been successfully planted in urban settings. The Hackberry has been a replacement tree for the American Elm where Dutch elm disease is a problem. The Hackberry is a good city tree because it is able to thrive in both hot, dry conditions and in moist, cool situations. It will tolerate both alkaline and acid conditions. The common Hackberry has been used in multi-row windbreak plantings to help control wind erosion. Due to its deep root system, the Hackberry helps prevent soil erosion. While the tree is generally pest free, it has a few limitations. One is witches’ broom: small clusters of twigs that grow from a single spot on a branch or the trunk. Sometimes, they can be found in large quantities throughout the tree. A new cultivar, ‘Prairie Pride, ’ offers good resistance to witches’ broom. The other problem associated with the Hackberry is nipple gall. This fairly common problem occurs when many wart-like growths appear on the bottom of leaves. Neither problem usually affects the health of the tree, but is aesthetically unattractive. The berries or drupes from the Hackberry are a favorite of cedar waxwings, robins and other birds throughout the winter. Other wildlife such as wild turkeys and ring-necked pheasant consume the fruit. While the Hackberry is not particularly valuable as a timber tree, it is occasionally used to make inexpensive furniture. Hackberry is commonly used as firewood. American Indians highly regarded the common Hackberry for medicinal, food and ceremonial objectives. Medicinally, the bark was boiled and an extraction came from this process, which was used to induce abortion and regulate problems with menstruation. The berries or drupes were mixed with corn and fat to make porridge. The Lakota were said to have used the berries as a flavoring for meat. Interestingly, the Lakota name for the Hackberry tree is Yamnumnugapi, meaning “crunching with teeth.” Hackberries can be found at a number of locations at WSU. A large mature Hackberry can be viewed on the southeast boulevard in front of Watkins Hall. A row of young Hackberry trees grow on the Mark Street boulevard just south of the Minné Hall parking lot
